DIDComm（Decentralized Identifier Communication）の暗号技術に関する初めての正式な分析を行い、ACM CCS 2024で発表予定

DIDCommの暗号技術に関する初めての正式な分析を行い、ACM CCS 2024で発表される予定です。

研究の主な成果：
・DIDCommの暗号化モデルを提示し、その仕様のセキュリティを証明しました。
・既存のモードの1つに対して、性能を2倍に向上させる改善案を提案しました。
・プライバシーを強化した新しいモードを提案しました。

DIDCommの2つの主要な暗号化モード（anoncryptとauthcrypt）とその組み合わせについて分析しました。

組み合わせモードの小さな弱点を特定し、簡単に修正可能な方法を提示しました。

新しい「ra-anon」モードを提案し、受信者の識別子を隠すことができるようになりました。これにより、SSI資格情報の受信をより匿名化できます。

提案された改善点は、JSON暗号化標準との互換性を考慮しています。

すべての詳細は、IACRのeprintで公開されている論文に記載されています。

In (3), our ra-anon mode *is* directly compatible with the underlying JSON standards!

Of course, for both (2) and (3), we prove that they are secure according to our DIDComm model.

Concerning implementation. In (2), our improved mode is not directly compatible with the JSON encryption standards, but these are easily extensible to incorporate it, so we think it is a very worthwhile improvement not only for DIDComm, but for the JSON encryption space at large.

For example, ra-anon would allow DIDComm users to receive SSI credentials without leaking to third parties that they are receiving these credentials! Sounds useful, eg, for anoncreds – which, by the way, are issued by some of the in-production projects using DIDComm.
Re: (3). All DIDComm modes leak the recipient(s)’ identifier(s). We give a simple mode (ra-anon) that hides them. We also specify how to combine our new mode with the existing ones.

Re: (2). The combination of anoncrypt and authcrypt duplicates a lot of work. We give an improved mode that saves one bulk data encryption and prevents duplicate identifiers. The former may save up to a few ms, and the latter a few hundreds of bytes – both, per DIDComm route hop.
No big deal, but better to keep it in mind. Excluding this easily fixable weakness, we prove that DIDComm’s spec is secure according to our model.

Re: (1). In our model and proof, we note that the combined mode doesn’t generally ensure that all recipients will receive the same message. This is fixable just by using AES-CBC+HMAC, which DIDComm supports off the shelf.
Also, DIDComm allows combining these modes, providing authenticated sender towards the recipient (but anonymous to third parties), and confidential messages.
DIDComm offers two main encryption modes: anoncrypt (anonymous sender, confidential message) and authcrypt (authenticated sender, confidential message).

Our results. We:

(1) Give a composable model of DIDComm’s encryption, and prove the security of its specification. We identify a minor weakness fixable without changing the protocol.

(2) Propose a 2x improvement for one of its modes.

(3) Propose a new privacy enhanced mode.
However, up to now, DIDComm lacked formal analysis. For cryptographers (and, indirectly, for everybody) this is no good, as DIDComm could pose certain security issues exploitable by attackers.

What is DIDComm? 

DIDComm is the main communications framework in the Self-Sovereign Identity (SSI) space. Pretty much like TLS for the rest of the world, but building on SSI. 

It is widely used in many production projects already so it is quite big in the domain.

Without standardization, identities and credentials issued by different organizations may not work seamlessly across apps and platforms, leading to fragmentation and inefficiencies

Privado ID addresses this challenge by following W3C standards to ensure global interoperability of decentralized identity systems:

- Decentralized Identifiers (DIDs): Let users create unique identifiers without permission from any authority –you can create them locally in your wallet, much like how you can create an Ethereum address

- Verifiable Credentials (VCs): Enable the private storage and content sharing of attributes about an identity (e.g. your government might issue you a verifiable credential that proves your date of birth). These credentials are stored in a standard format so that any verifier can read and understand it.

These two standards—DIDs and VCs—are key to how Privado ID operates to ensure interoperability across different platforms and apps
